A little disappointed. I wanted it to be soo much better, but still ok.  I wouldn't come back though.  Meza grill is a lot better. Don't order the ballerina drink. As for food the chorizo corn off the cob was the best, tasty and spicy. The filet was a too salty, but definitely much better than their Cesar salad. All in all ok, but I'd rather spend my money else where.

Cesar, our server was great so does Efren.  Very attentive!  We're so impressed.  However, the 2 hostesses tonight was !  They seemed to be checking something in the computer but were giggling while we wait to be greeted.  The other male host from Omnia who I thought was a guest was talking to them... I move forward to see what these two hostesses were doing in the computer and they were checking something on line!  While the line builds up!  When the hostess in black felt that I was checking what they were on... She changed the screen to the seating arrangement screen... Busted!!!!  And sat us.  They don't have name tags and we did not bother to ask.  So far food was good especially the crab cake and Mac and cheese!  Again,  just thumbs down on the 2 hostesses.

Perhaps the kitchen was having an off night but the food in here was proactively bad. Short rib was dry/bland. Ceviche was sad/tired and lacked any citrus punch. Mushroom and buratta was flavorless. The only reason I don't give it 1 star are the brussel sprouts were delicious and the service was pretty friendly...although the server didn't ask why we left the short rib completely uneaten. Overall a huge bummer for what we were expecting.

Very overpriced!!! Food was good but not in any way outstanding. Service was very good but didn't make up for the other negatives. Won't go back. Seriously doubt if this restaurant is still in business a year from now.

Brought my girlfriend here for her birthday. The meal was awesome! My girlfriend is a vegetarian, although I've recently gotten her to try some fish. They made small plates special for her. First was a salad with mixed greens, strawberries, candied walnuts,  and a raspberry vinaigrette...very good. For me they brought the pork belly...delicious!!! 2nd round they unfortunately brought her another salad...not the ideal place for vegetarians I must say, nonetheless, the 2nd salad had figs and goat cheese and greens with a delicious dressing...she said it was excellent, I liked it too! With the delicious, spicy bread balls we had initially, we were already feeling full, so she canceled her main course and we split the tuna. My vegetarian girlfriend loved it! lol I also really enjoyed it! Sushi grade with the skin attached...really tasty! Overall, a great restaurant...highly recommend!

I expected better, Searsucker!!

We came for dinner on a Sunday and ordered 3 appetizers, and 3 entrees over four people. The service was good, and our server seemed to know a lot about the menu and recommended some dishes that we ended up ordering.

Here's my report:
crab cake jumbo lump + fennel + aioli - delicious 
short rib "the harlot" + horseradish + fried onion - probably the highlight of the meal
artichoke hearts + cheddar + mozzarella - this was a dip with poor execution - this is why. They gave us a very large portion of this cheesy dip with three pieces of bread. When we asked for more bread (more than half the dip left with no toast) we were told that they would have to charge us for it.
pork butt - standard, nothing special
butcher steak - did not try this, however the presentation was nice.

Sorry, but when you're spending $200+ on a meal I'd expect to receive a sufficient amount of bread to go with my dip. 

Return Factor: None.

Dined here on a Saturday night for a party of six and had a great time. Drinks were tasty and refreshing. My favorite was the strawberry jalapeño margarita. Our server was very knowledgeable and suggested some scrumptious dishes. For starters, our table had two orders of the following: bone marrow, calamari steak and duck fat fries. For the main course we had the 36 oz Tomahawk ribeye with sautéed mushroom side, New York Steak with corn jalapeño, two orders of fish and chips, braised pork, grilled cheese and tomato soup for the kids. Everything was delicious but the Tomahawk was a tad too salty and cooked Medium rather than the Medium-rare we preferred. 
The star of the meal was the bone marrow. We all agreed that the next time we come back we will just order ten of those bone marrow!
We were too full to try any desserts. Our server gave us chips for free expedited access to Omnia. It was a busy night for Omnia being it was its two-year anniversary and Kaskade as the main dj but we did not have any problem getting in. I'm already planning on coming back when we go to Vegas again next month.

Incredibly bad service. Took 3 hours from when we sat down till they finally figured out our bill. The manager was busy flirty with all off the waitstaff. The entire serving staff was talking and not paying attention to our table. I had to go to the bar on several occasions to get our drinks. 

At the end of the meal our server took 45 minutes. ( not exaggerating) to get the ticket right. I was added items that I did not order. Finally after asking the manager to fix the error I paid 20 bucks extra in cash just to leave. 

Food was not worth all the hassle. Plenty of options I would stay clear until they fix the service. Ruined the night.

I wouldn't even waste money to go there again.
The food is pretty horrible.
I got a salmon and it was that worst I had in a long time.
The location I would say is nice and inviting but that's pretty much it

This is the best new restaurant in Vegas!  It's also a rarity being an eating establishment on the Strip that has a Happy Hour!  We went to Happy Hour after reading the great reviews.  We were not disappointed at all.  

The food we ate was tremendous.  The crab cake was as good as we have ever had, be in Boston or Baltimore.  The shrimp and grits, while advertised as spicy, is not spicy enough to keep my wife's delicate palate from loving it!  The strawberry champagne salad is unique and superb!  As other people have stated, the portions are better than most Happy Hour foods.  We finished the meal off with the pumpkin dessert, very good.  

What so many restauranteurs don't realize is that a good Happy Hour draws people in to sample your food, service, and cocktails.  If you pass that step, then you have customers who are coming back regardless of being Happy Hour or not. That is us.  We will come back for the pork butt, the filet, the salmon entree, the mahi, the scallops, etc.  The prices on those dishes aren't outrageous.  They aren't the best, but if you have dined on the Strip, you know you are paying top dollar.  At least here you get fantastic, friendly service and exceptional food.  

FWIW, I've owned a restaurant, been a general manager, a bar manager, a bartender, and a waitperson, oh, and along with a dish washer.  I am judging this eatery on one visit, but boy, it was an unbelievably exceptional visit.  

We will be back!

Oh, forgot to mention a pet peeve of mine they overcame.  Sitting at the bar, Searsucker had more than one person wait on you, EVEN ask you if you want another drink or some more water!  What mattered to them was if you had good service, not whether a certain bartender waited on you.  Good job, Searsucker!
Ahhhmazing food great service accommodated a large group of friends for his bachelor party great place to have dinner while in LV and waiting to get into Ominia

Food was ok I was hoping it would be the same as the sear sucker  in San Diego but the food was just bland . The squid was good though just too saucy for me . We also had the duck fat fries nothing special , tuna albacore and spinach salad. This place is next to the omnia night club.

Seersucker is a case of "just fine" food in a great location. They're in a prime Caesar's location and offer (for Ceasars) pretty reasonable prices. 

We made a reservation and I'd advise you to do that, since Searsucker seems rather popular. It's a good sized space with modern furniture and a menu that encourages sharing. We started with corn muffins ($5) and hot damn!!! these are some tasty bites - a bit spicy, full of bacon and served with sweet butter. Yum! 

For dinner, I had a Cobb salad ($16?) which was ok - I asked for dressing in the side and never revived any at all. See: service, below.

My dining companions opted for more meaty choices and seemed happy. Our side of mac''cheese ($16) was overly salty but used wagon wheel pasta which made me happy.


Service...yeah, not the best. Our server was honestly kind of bitchy for no reason. I didn't get a side of salad dressing and didn't want to ask because she was attitude-y Judy & I didn't want spit infused ranch. I'm guessing with a different server this place would be 4 for me.
Nice selection of small plates and cocktails. The service was great, and we enjoyed our meal. I definitely will come back on my next Vegas trip!

Not worth the money at all! Their options of small plates are pretty limited but the dumbfounded aspect is finding out the grilled chicken addition to our salad was more expensive than the actual salad. It was $15 while the salad alone was $12. I wish the server told us prior rather than us finding out on the bill.

First time- Great wine and food. I didn't take pictures of the apps but I highly suggest the. Calamari steak and duck fat fries. I had the 6oz filet medium rare and it was come to perfection. The creamy kale added to the flavor, which a happy mouth.
My friends 2lb lobster was fabulous. It was juicy and easy to open up and eat.

A large group of us came here for dinner a few weeks ago. First off, our waitress (I believe her name is Lindsey - shorter and blond?) was wonderful!! She knew the whole menu, and she never missed a beat with our group.

Drinks:
When Doves Cry - Two thumbs up
Snake in the Grass - meh. Too sweet, it didn't taste like it had any alcohol in it.
We had a taste of a syrah that was just terrible. Maybe it had been open too long, or maybe the wine was just that bad. 
We had more cocktails and quite a few wines, but I don't remember enough about them to post anything.

Food:
Braised Pork Butt - Tasty, more than enough food by itself!
Scallops - Great, definitely worth ordering
Bigeye Tuna - Very good, though it could have used a little more flavor to kick it up a notch
Tacos - looked good but were itty bitty. Some of the smallest tacos I have ever seen. The warm spinach salad looked a little on the small side too. Though spinach really shrinks up with heat so maybe that is why.

Also, for those wondering...the things listed under 'Jars and Sliced' literally come in a jar. Not great if you are sharing, but fun if it is just for you.

Overall, a great option for dinner close to the strip!

Inside Caesars, you find this gem. Loved the decor! We all shared the huge (36oz) and amazing tomahawk steak - feed 6 people. Mac n cheese was bomb! Brussel sprouts and walnuts delish!  Service was good. You won't be disappointed with the food. Only gripe is that we could only do the happy hour drinks at the bar, not offered 5-7pm in dinning room.

This is the first time in Vegas and we arrived late to our hotel (Ceasar's). The searsucker was one of the only restaurants open at the time; the ambiance appeared nice from the outside, so we have it a shot. 1st look at menu revealed extremely high prices ($46 for fish and chips!). Our experience was that food was average at best and not worth the cost. Duck fat fries, which we were told was one of the specialties, was not savory. The best appetizer was the steak calamari. The best part of our experience at this restaurant was service; our waitress was outstanding, attentive, and very friendly. Also, food arrived fast. Overall, we felt food was not worth cost, and being from NYC, I am somewhat accustomed to pricey places but expect quality in return!
The pork butt was so moist and delicious, with the apple slaw on top it set it off. The Brussels sprouts were under cooked and did not have good flavor. The duck fat fries were amazing!

I was soo happy to make it this restaurant for dinner on Saturday... We missed our original reservation and had to change it several times that night... Luckily, we made it to the restaurant at 11:40pm and made it for the "late night" menu..

Everything we ordered was bomb, with the exception of one dish... 

Need to order: duck fat fries + tomato jam,  "Caesar" romaine + kale + egg + parm, and short rib "the harlot" + horseradish + fried.. ALL TASTY AND YUMMY!!

One dish that was not on the "late night" menu was-- beet + radish + crème fraîche + goat cheese WHICH the kitchen was able to make for us-- AWESOME!! VERY YUMMY!!

Dessert to order: S'mores Bar--  Graham + salted caramel ganache + honey 
chocolate mousse + marshmallow + chocolate ice cream + cookie crumble... ABSOLUTELY SCRUMPTIOUS!!


I was disappointed about the-- farm bird lollipops + hot sauce + bleu.  I can handle spicy, but this was soo spicy I couldn't enjoy it.  We didn't ask for it to be taken off the bill, but the waitress should've asked when she noticed we didn't like it when only of the lollipops were missing from the dish (which was on my plate) when we asked her to take it away.  

Other than that, our overall experience was great!!  I live in southern California and totally looking forward to visiting the San Diego location in the near future...

Had such an AMAZING dinner! The food was fantastic, ambiance was great and our server Chris made our experience. He was so helpful and gave great recommendations. Would definitely recommend the calamari, NY steak, and SCALLOPS. The craft cocktails were really tasty. Can't wait to try other locations. Will be back for sure!

One of the many, many places just around the corner within the giant maze that is Caesars.

Went here for happy hour.  Had about six small plates.  The spicy shrimp ceviche was excellent.  The artichoke heart cheese dip was not good (the artichoke hearts were tough).  The mushrooms were a little dry.  The duck fat dipped fries were nice and the ketchup had a little kick in it which was nice.  The shrimp remoulade was pretty tangy.

Overall, a nice place to get a bite right after work.

And our server was named Caesar; although I suspect they are all named Caesar.

What a great food!!!! OMG! We ordered so many things of the menu and absolutely everything was top notch. And what a cute waiter...^^
Also, if a person spends $50 you get a no line chip to get to OMNIA. Good deal for this amazing food and drinks!

I had the Cobb with honey mustard dressing and it was fantastic and the ginger smash was perfect.  I watched a few people order happy hour items that all looked great!   Service (mine was Philip) was laid back not too slow but not all up in your business either.  I would come back.

The wife and I dined at Searsucker on a Sunday night.  We had no problem getting a table for two at 7:30.  We started off with a round of drinks.  Searsucker's cocktails and house-made infusions were solid.  I had the Kinda Old Fashioned ($18) made with Jack Single Barrel whiskey, Montenegro Amaro, Ancho Reyes liqueur, sweet vermouth, old fashioned syrup, and bitters.  It was boozy and bitter with the right amount of sweetness.  The wife's Jalaberry Strawpeno ($13) was a jalapeno and strawberry infused tequila with lime and agave.  It was a nice, fresh take on a margarita.  For our food, we shared orders of the Blistered Shishito Peppers ($11), Calamari Steak ($16), and Fish & Chips ($42).  All of the dishes were tasted good to outstanding.  The Fish & Chips, a beautifully presented fried whole branzino with waffle cut, sweet potato chips, was excellent, but I felt a bit overpriced.  The Blistered Shishito Peppers were the closest thing to a miss for me.  They were blistered, but possessed a wilted texture that seemed like they were more steamed than roasted over a fire or in a hot skillet.  However, the Calamari Steak, thick cuts of calamari deep fried to a perfect fork tenderness and topped with a chili honey glaze, was the standout dish and the best fried calamari dish I've ever had.

Searsucker was a pleasant surprise.  Frankly, given the lineup of celebrity chef-driven restaurants in Las Vegas, let alone in Caesars Palace, Searsucker seemed to me to be somewhat of an afterthought, a backup plan restaurant choice.  Searsucker deserves better than that as they're easily Caesars' best bet for tasty comfort food.

Went with a large party and had the chance to try tons of small plates. The pork belly appetizer is a stand-out item. We also had the shrimp and grits (good), squid (ok), tuna himachi (heard it was good, don't like sushi), and crab cake (very good). I got the scallops with cous cous. The scallops were perfectly cooked and a decent size. Tried the corn off the cob which was good not awesome, but good. I was stuffed by the end of the meal. Perrier Jouet sold by the glass made this place even better!

Spend $50 or more and it gets you into the omini no line. 
Tapas:
Crab cakes: too salty, fishy & the crust was soggy.
Strawberry pecan salad: over priced
Habinero  Pepper & pickles: too briny with a kick of spice.
Bone marrow: nothing special, fatty oily marrow with onion jam over two tiny pieces of toast.

But getting into the club without waiting was nice.

This is by far my favorite meal in Vegas! Take my advice, and go to this place around 5-6pm. They have a great happy hour menu.  I've had a lot of burgers in my life, and this HAS to be the best I've had. Upgrade to the duck fat fries for a dollar, trust me you won't regret that extra dollar.  This place is A++ in my book and would highly recommend it. For you whiskey drinkers, get the "Bad Bad." All in all, this place is fairly pricey, but if you go during the happy hour menu, you won't pay through the nose for a fantastic meal.

After finding several bars downtown were closed for New Year's day, we went back to the strip for happy hour.

Searsucker is a southern influenced gastropub, with a really great happy hour featuring $9 Old-fashioneds and $2 oysters (not just the standard bluepoints everyone is giving you nowadays.) We also had sliders and bone marrow ($2 per bone at happy hour.)

The star of the visit was the fried pigs ear. They are cut into small strips, marinated for hours and then lightly fried, for a more delicate texture than you're expecting. They are deliciously salty with an appropriate hit of tartness. 

The oysters come prepared with a mignonette of micro mint and pomegranate. Each oyster rests on a thick salt bed, which we viewed as a little fussy. I also took off the mint leaves as they interfered with the oyster flavor. The pomegranate, on the other hand, is a great pairing.

The old-fashioneds were prepared classically and well-balanced. This is definitely the best choice for happy hour in Caesar's Palace and perhaps the entire Strip.

Happy Hour review:

I came here for Happy Hour. To drink, I got the bad bad t-roy brown. I don't typically order cocktails but I really liked this one. I ordered two. The first one was great. The second was good but it didn't seem like it was muddled/mixed well enough. I also ordered the potato fries, pork chips and short rib sandwich. The portions were much bigger than I expected. Everything was good. The potato fries were great. I liked the chipotle ketchup. The short rib in the short rib sandwich was good. I think the bread was a bit too thick so it wasn't balanced. I ended up picking out some of the meat and the onions. The pork chips were good but I thought the sauce was just a tad too sweet. I think Seersucker is a solid choice for Happy Hour.

This is a must eat place!!! Everything was perfection! Delicious!!!

Do it! You'll thank me later I promise
Got the roasted chicken and it was very dry. Was disappointed for how much it cost! Also our server was very snoody!

We took a group of ten and ordered virtually every appetizer on the menu. The cauliflower, macaroni, fig toast, hummus, and brussels spouts were pretty good. I wasn't a fan of the bone marrow or pigs ears (though the guy sitting to my left was). The caprese was ok (my wife really liked it, though). The bread part of the caprese was burnt and too hard in my opinion. 

If all we'd gotten were appetizers and it hadn't taken 30 minutes to get them, it would be a four-star review. 

However, and just speaking for my main course, it was nasty. The waiter did a good job selling me on the special--a portion of the 75 lb. pig they'd just roasted. They brought me a pile of pork, yes, but it was cold and very grisly. I couldn't eat more than a couple of pieces. Very disappointing. 

The atmosphere was also very loud, and although the waiter knows the menu well, he spoke too fast and in a rote fashion--clearly a result of having repeated the same thing too many times, so between that and the loud background (music in addition to other people), we had to ask him to repeat himself several times. 

I guess when you spend over $800 on a meal, you expect the food and service to be excellent.

Wow, this place is awful. 

The atmosphere screams tacky sports bar. The whole place feels as if you're sitting in a food court with giant flat screens everywhere, including the cheap furniture and uncomfortable chairs. Poorly lit and loud. 

And this is the sort of place where the servers try to jack up the bill as high as they can. You know, where they ask if you would like water and then charge you $9 for a bottle of Fiji without asking you. Or letting you order a $10 side of fries with an entree that already comes with french fries. As if the $65 steak entrees weren't over-priced enough. 

The service timing is horrible, too. Despite the prices, this is NOT fine dining by any stretch of the imagination. These folks have no idea what they are doing when it comes to service. 

And to top it all off, the food is bland and overly salty. Horrible. The $18 rib starter that we had was so dreadful that we scaled back our entire dinner plans and decided less would definitely be the theme of the evening. 

The wine list is equally pretentious and over-priced. $125 for wine that retails for $15 at the grocery store. Other mediocre bottles that are priced in the $600(!?!?!) range. Please.

If you have very little experience with fine dining, you might mistake expensive for quality. Don't be fooled. Michelin is not going to be calling these folks anytime soon.

Best thing to order here is the bone marrow, well flavored with brussel sprouts and butter that along with the marrow, melts in your mouth.  The lollipop wings were good, chocolate sammies were delicious, duck fat fries were overly seasoned with not even a hint of duck fat taste, but the worst item I had was the braised pork butt.  The pork butt had no flavor besides the pickled tower laid on top.  It was confusing, the pickled vegetables dominated the flavor of the meat, not even letting the true taste exude through the anticipated braised flavor.  Even the smell of the pork had no inviting aroma, very bland.  Staff (such as our server, Cesar who was nice enough to have the pork butt and fries removed from our bill due to our dissatisfaction) and service were excellent, but the braised pork butt...was a bunch of "malarkey."
The staff was the best we had all week in Vegas! Great for watching March Madness games & the food was delicious!
Mixed drinks are expensive but go for the Happy Hour and get the Bone Marrow (only twenty bucks) and DELICIOUS. Servers are very kind and the food was very good.

Definitely not worth the money.... food was cold  and awful I had the drunkenskirt steak..salty and undercooked I asked for med well and got med rare. Fries were awful as well. My husband had the Thanksgiving meal it was just ok but definitely not worth $49....at best I wud say $19.99. The service was less than stellar. Had to ask for stuff a minimum of 3 times before I got it. Needless to say won't be going back?

Came here after a nice day at the pool and my experience was amazing! Lindsey my waitress was so helpful and made great recommendations. I had the Duck which was out of this world! From the ambiance to the service to the food Searsucker Las Vegas is amazing!

Ugh, where do I start. 

Went here as it seemed to be one of the more decently priced and more interesting places on the strip. Unfortunately it kinda sucked. Not the food but just about everything else. 

There was a short wait for a table so we were offered a high top or the seats facing the casino floor if we wanted to be seated immediately. I like people watching so facing out was a great place to sit. We ordered the hamachi and jalapeño plate to start along with a couple of beers. The beers took a little bit longer than they should, but the amount of time the hamachi took was appalling. The insulting part was that this dish definitely fits the description of a small plate, it was basically 3 crisps with a slice of the hamachi and vegetables/sauce. The dish itself was great, the cucumbers and jalapeño  worked so well with the fish, tasted incredible. But for what amounts to 3 chips with a slice of fish on them to take over 20 minutes to prepare was pretty bad. 

We had also ordered the Ono and a beet salad with goat cheese. The only odd request we had was for the goat cheese to come on the side which isn't a substitution or anything out of line. When the runner came out with them the goat cheese was breaded (not indicated on the menu) and mixed in with the salad. We politely sent it back and requested the goat cheese on the side and not breaded, and some silverware. Our waitress then came back with the salad sans goat cheese. She said she would get some for us and also offered to get some silverware. After waiting several more minutes I just turned around and asked the bartender for silverware. My Ono was no longer warm enough but it was very good. 

Unfortunately lack of staff communication and attentiveness ruined this place for me. This is too bad as the food was awesome.
Good location inside of Caesars Palace, next to Omina night club, New style of American cuisine, food size big .

Long story short: how many times have you sat at home watching the Food Network or some cooking show on TV and thought 'wow that looks interesting' and wished you could try it yourself?  

Some of the menu options and flavor combinations are definitely different and might intimidate those who like to play it safe but hey, youre in Vegas! Get out of your comfort zone, be adventurous, try something new! We tried a little bit of everything and it was all good.

No room for dessert.

I can't say enough about our dining experience at Searsucker! The staff was absolutely amazing- friendly, funny, knowledgable, and extremely attentive. The food was out of this world good. I opted to get a few starters as my meal because I just couldn't decide on what to get. The cocktails are equally as delicious as the food. 

When we were planning our trip, this was one of my top choices, and it didn't disappoint. We started with the shishito peppers, which I would highly recommend. I got the bacon and eggs and the brussel sprouts. My husband got a steak and asparagus. He's a picky eater and not easy to please, and nearly a week later, he is still talking about how great the food was. We shared the cookies and milk for dessert, and it was such a fun, cozy way to end a fantastic meal.

The open kitchen only adds to the experience. You can see, hear, and smell your food being prepared, and it's such a treat. 

I can't wait to come back!

Cheddar Puffers. 
Duck Fat Fries.
Mushrooms + Burrata + Toast.
Crab Cake Jumbo Lump.
Pork Butt.
Cookies & Milk.

Fun Décor + Delicious Food = Happy Camper. :)

This restaurant was a good size and well decor with cool lights. 

Bacon eggs (4/5) 
Bone marrow (5/5) - I wish there was more bone marrow
Mexican shrimps (4/5) 
Mac and cheese (3/5) - the mac was not as soft as I like
Calamari steak (5/5) 
Bread pudding (4/5)
Cookie ice cream (4/5) 

Overall, great food and nice ambiance. I think the appetizers and shared plates section had better food choices than the main entrees. I definitely would come
Back

I recently went to Searsucker with some work friends and it was great time! The food was great, the service was great and the atmosphere was fun! 

The best way to describe the food here is that is something that you will recognize. It's not like some of the other Las Vegas restaurants where you have no idea what the dish consists of. We just ordered a bunch of different plates and shared. The Calamari steak was great! Sweet and tangy and cooked just right! We ordered the Chef's salad and the field greens and pear salad. Very simple salads, with the right flavor. The entrees were the NY Strip, scallops and scampi. The Scampi stood out because it was large, grilled prawns on a bed of squash spaghetti. Never had squash spaghetti before and that was pretty good! Light and overwhelming but a very pleasant flavor. Scallops were awesome! Not much more to say. The NY strip was cooked just right and came with a red wine sauce. All in all a great set of entrees. Desert was warm cookies and cold milk! An old classic but still delicious! The deconstructed key lime pie was my highlight of the night. Didn't expect much from it but it was an amazing flavor (Does come with coconut)!

Mark was our server and he did a great job taking care of us. He even recommended some drinks that had the same alcohol so that our group wasn't mixing! That's attention to detail!

A friend invited me to Searsucker for a late dinner on a Friday night. Our reservations weren't until 10PM, and the place was bustling when we arrived. We were seated within 5 minutes and led to a small table by a window. Our server and busser introduced themselves promptly and looked quite dapper, if I might add. The menu was filled with interesting choices, but the vegetarian selection was miniscule. 

BALLERINA AND THE CZAR ($14): My friend started off with this specialty cocktail, which she said was tasty. I was content with my fancy glass of water. :) 4/5

HABANERO & CORIANDER PICKLE: This was FREE with our Yelp check-in. I hate pickles, so I didn't touch this small appetizer. My friend said they weren't that spicy, but cautioned that she has a heightened tolerance for spicy foods due to her Vietnamese upbringing. 3/5

CHEDDAR PUFFERS: Our server brought these out to us, and I assumed they were complimentary. They reminded me of the bread served at the Eiffel Tower Restaurant at the Paris Casino (except the ones at Eiffel are better!). I thought they were kind of bland. 3/5

QUINOA ($23): This was the only dinner entree option available to me as a veg head. I have difficulty describing this dish. My friend called it 'earthy' after she tasted it. I called it 'grainy'. It was a-okay. 3/5

HANGER BUTCHER STEAK ($32): She ordered the steak and loved it. Awesome presentation, too. 5/5

ERMAHGERD SUNDAE ($10): We shared this and settled on it mainly because the name sounded so hilarious. Not a fan, though. The brownies tasted stale and store bought. The 'gelato' tasted like regular ice cream. 2/5

VIBE: It was extremely loud inside the restaurant and difficult to carry on a conversation. The music was on full blast and the place was packed. I was yelling, not talking. As for the window view, at first we were happy to have the view, but that soured when guys waiting in line to get into Omnia next door began tapping on the glass window and gesturing at us through the window. :/ 2/5 

SERVICE: Perfect! Our plates were cleared away quickly and we were checked on frequently. 4.5/5

Worth a Return Visit?
I'm interested in trying out the Happy Hour menu but don't see myself coming back for dinner. I'm hoping it will be less rambunctious earlier on in the day.

YELP 100 CHALLENGE 2015: #176

Located in Caesars', and opened by managing partner Hakkasan to coincide with nearby Omnia, celebrity chef Brian Malarkey's fourth (actually fifth if you count the shuttered Scottsdale experiment) Searsucker bills itself as New American Classic Cuisine, and although the ebb and flow of such restaurants in major Casinos has become a virtual game of 'who's who, and who's new' an early visit seemed perfectly suited to a nearby concert, myself and three friends sitting down at the end of the open kitchen away from the hustle of a three-deep bar.

Undoubtedly courting the cool kids from the nightclub nextdoor with all sorts of clever libations and a late night menu that goes until 3am, but surprisingly pulling a wide demographic despite loud music ranging from VAST to Pearl Jam and Alice in Chains, it was with greetings from a server ported direct from the San Diego flagship that our dining began and with complimentary cheese puffs tinged in peppers whetting the palate it was not long until Chef JP Labadie stopped by to discuss the menu, a few of our desired items from the online version already culled as the kitchen ramps up to full speed.

Energetic, if not a little bit 'cramped,' with plenty of eye candy both on the walls and amongst the service staff it was with appetites gauged and questions answered that an order was formulated and requesting that items be sent out in trios so as not to overwhelm the service was nearly spotless from beginning to end, a high piece of praise in a city where such a thing is quite rare.

Starting with 'smalls' before progressing to greens, ocean, farms, 'and', and 'all milk + sugar,' it was in a trio of Malarkey's signatures that original opinions were formed and although the brie presented pasty and bland beneath the jam with a substantial delay for an extra piece of bread further marring the experience, no fault could be found in either the 'harlot' or the 'belly,' both of the expectedly rich proteins featuring great depth of flavor and textbook texture amidst accoutrements lent levity through the utilization of restrained herbs and spice.

Continuing the small plates it was once again a 'toast' that proved least impressive of round two, and although the burrata got lost amidst all the fungus and spongy bread just like the brie beneath strawberries both the Searsucker signature Shrimp and Grits as well as the Rocky Mountain Oysters were better than expected, the first for somehow finding a way to reinvent a dish done countless places as a spicy sort of cioppino while the second plated the lightly fried gonads with crispy greens and a tangy vinaigrette plus onion jam that was both smoky and sweet.

Taking a lighter approach, albeit only slightly, course three consisted of three plates focused around vegetables and although prior plates were good it was here that the first two 'stunners' arrived, the Strawberry salad a nice and refreshing share plate but the sweetbread salad and spicy pork-infused cream corn undoubtedly stealing all the thunder, the spinach beneath buttermilk and a poached egg with bacon selling itself like an gussied up Lyonnaise with the creamy bits of offal adding just enough funk to let you know they are there.

Onward to mains, savories concluded with a somewhat mixed bag, for as much as I commend the kitchen for serving the duck nearly rare I only wish the effort would have been rewarded by accoutrements that served to accent rather than overwhelm, a theme of sweetness and smoke also found in the braised Pork Butt and seared Mahi, though with far more restraint - the fish in particular perhaps the best of its kind with boozy cherries finding a deft dance partner in charred white flesh.

Unwilling and unable to forgo sweets, particularly at a place so routinely celebrated for its pastry program, it was with some restraint that I avoided requesting 'the lot,' but still investing heavily in 4/6 of the selections one would be hard pressed to name a single plate that failed to shine, even the seemingly overwrought sundae presenting a lovely blend of textures and flavors with more than enough to share while both the crostata and pumpkin cake were unassuming yet perfect, the heavy hitting S'mores bar a dish best shared, though so compelling as a result of the combination of honey, caramel, and chocolate that none will be left on the plate regardless of stomach capacity or party size.

Already functioning at a high level, and seemingly willing to take *some* chances without going 'all in,' Searsucker enters a market crowded with several similar restaurants and with longtime Las Vegas Chef Labadie at the helm an early look gives one hope that this won't just be another absentee landlord hotspot for pre-and-post-club noshing, a decision likely to be made by the powers that be in upcoming months as feedback and finances curate the cuisine.

This place was an awesome surprise. My husband and I stopped in for drinks, but the menu looked so great and the bar staff was awesome so we decided to stay for dinner. We split the happy hour sliders (ordered 2), the goat cheese salad (forgot the name), and the pasta. All were fantastic. We liked it so much that we went back later for dessert. We'll definitely be back.

Tip, eat at the bar during happy hour (4-7 PM)!

We went for dinner before a show after reading many good reviews and we're not disappointed! The food was delicious and the wait staff was incredibly kind and knowledgeable about bith the menu and pairing options. I would highly recommend this place!

Staff needs an attitude adjustment. We we greeted with a bitchy face and no warm greeting. We made it in time for happy hour, but our server took so long to get to us that we couldn't order it.
One of my friends had the tacos and got FOOD POISONING because of the very questionable meat.
The prices are too high for the amount of food. And service wasn't helpful when one dish needed to be sent back. None of the staff was smiling.
Except Curtis the busser. He was incredibly kind and sociable. He gave our table more attention than our server. 
We felt judged being younger customers since we didn't buy alcohol, but we could still afford to pay and tip well...
We never got our beverages refilled.
I had the roasted chicken here. It was well seasoned. The decor is great here. The service was great.

I cannot say how fantastic our experience was! We went for an early dinner on a Saturday night and the service was great. We ordered a couple of items I read reviews about on Yelp and they were AMAZING!

I had the eggs and bacon and let me tell you I would drive across town just to have that again and again and again!

We also ordered the short rib. Excellent.

My husband had the Pork Butt entree based on our waitress, Tammy's, recommendation. He was not disappointed!

The table next to us ordered the bone marrow. Apparently, a waiter in the Austin restaurant started a trend of pouring a shot of bourbon through the bone to get any remaining marrow. Keep that in mind if you order the bone marrow! Sounds fantastic.

Dessert was good too. Interesting though that as stellar as the entrees and small plates were the desserts weren't quite as outstanding (and I am a dessert fiend). However, Tammy did recommend the cookies and we opted for the s'mores and sundae. Again, they were very good, just not as outstanding as the other food. Tammy said that she bakes cookies at home and the cookies there are the best she's ever had. Definitely trying the cookies next time.

FYI - the music is loud and there are no soft surroundings. Be prepared for it to be noisy.

We will definitely be returning!

Searsucker was good but I had higher expectations for it, being inside a casino on the strip. The service was good but not excellent. What upset me the most were the drinks. I got a mixed drink and the proportions didn't seem right and tasted horrible. The other guests at my table ordered different mixed drinks and had the same result to the point where none of us finished our drinks. The food was actually tasty and well-made. I enjoyed the scallops and their version of the Mac and cheese. Would come back again to give it another chance on the drinks.

Went on a Saturday night.  Service was good, not great but good.  We did the chefs recommended Apps for a table of 7, all of which were great!  Those were eaten quickly.  Entrees were pretty blah, seemed to be missing seasonings.  I would say check with place out for apps and a drink, I'd skip dinner.  They had Calvin Harris playing at the night club next to the restaurant so it was extremely loud and noisy right outside the restaurant.

went here for dinner one night and it was AMAZING! the service was great but the food was even better!!

we got the bone marrow, duck fat fries and some beer braised short ribs. it was literally like i died and went to heaven once i ate the bone marrow! it was so rich and sweet! the short ribs were so tender and melted in your mouth.. & you can never go wrong with duck fat fries ;)

would definitely recommend to anyone who is adventurous with food! i will be coming back when i'm back in Vegas.

This place was actually great we had some Habenero pickles to start off then we had blue cheese chicken skewers 

Drinks were a little expensive but good

Much better than I was expecting. The beer list included some interesting options. The bartenders were fun and lively and engaging. The crab and avocado appetizer was killer... big chunks of crab and fresh avocado and nice subtle spice. I wish they included more than 4 chips, but that would be my only complaint. The short rib entree was cooked perfectly and dwarfed the short rib I had at Gordan Ramsay's a couple nights prior. The portion was very generous. This is a strong contender.

Great addition to Caesars... Do not walk in w/out a reservation during meal times.

Beef tartare and biscuits were amazing, along with the short rib and desserts.

Only negatives were the service is hard to come by if eating at the bar and can be a little slow (but attentive). Once brought to our server's attention, Charles came over to help and he was an amazing server. The only other negative were the drinks were not strong.. which is sad because they tasted great!
Perfect. Soup, appetizer, food all delicious. I am very picky person and don't give 5 Star easily. This place, ambiance,servers,kitchen all 5 stars. This is the one Of the best place for a dining.

Went there for dinner last week and boy were we not disappointed.  The Pork Belly with egg is so yummy.  The chicken lollypops are a nice twist on a chicken wing.  Very flavorful.  The albacore with prosciutto was very nice.  A different twist on Tuna.  All the cocktails are great, but my favorite was the honey badger which was made with  rye and fresh lemon + honey syrup.  MMMMMMM

A little pricey in my opinion for the food here. The servt and everything was fine, just the food was ok. The scallops I get were good, but not great


Also I hated the roasted cauliflower. Both my friend and I who ordered it barely ate ours. The seasoning was awful on it.

Not really a great place for vegetarians. I can usually find something pretty decent to eat at most restaurants. However, I was pretty disappointed with my menu options. The only entree was the quinoa dish which was basically a soggy mound of quinoa with a little bit of steamed spinach underneath, topped with a few shreds of raw carrots and some micro greens. The dish was very bland and disappointing for $23. The beet salad was pretty good. It had golden beet chunks with a creaming dressing. And there were these two little fried cheese balls that were a nice surprise! Overall, it had a Nice sweet flavor but was a very small portion. The best dish was the side of brussels spouts with walnuts. They were charred with balsamic, tangy and tender. 

Service was average, and food was average as well. Nothing stood out about this experience that would warrant s repeat visit.
I always heard about the one in San Diego so I had to come in for the grand opening, let me tell you this is what vegas needed! Great food, drinks and service!

Unbelievable Old Fashions!  We stopped here before seeing Celine at Caesar's and their world famous Old Fashions are incredible.  The food was fantastic and we had a great time.  Try the PB&J Old Fashion...it's their most popular drink.
Outstanding. Tasty. Great staff and service. So good to have this in CP.
I shared a couple of plates with my friends.  The short rib with mashed potatoes was the best dish out of all the ones we ordered.  If you are eating here, you have GOT to try it!

Food tasted good, but the menu wasnt specific as to what was included in each item. For example, my companion had a burger that had a little bit of a green spread on it. Turns out it was an avocado spread and she is allergic to avocados. The server was not very attentive as we had to track her down for the bill.

    Searsucker Las Vegas is located right next to OMNIA nightclub at Caesars Palace hotel. It's by the Celebrity Chef Brian Malarkey. Designed by critically-acclaimed interior designer, Thomas Schoos, Searsucker's comfortable living spaces, retro Americana vibe, New American Classic dishes and specialty cocktails set the mood for an epic night ahead. We'll plan your entire dining experience; what happens afterwards is completely up to you.
  
  Happy hour in Las Vegas never tasted so good! Why would you stay in your room when you could have a Peter Rabbit cocktail, instead? Searsucker is bringing you the Las Vegas happy hour you always wanted. Alongside our specialty cocktails and house infusions, indulge in a few of our signature dishes at discounted prices.

  Chef Brian Malarkey's playful dinner menu sets Searsucker apart from other Las Vegas strip restaurants with its imaginative twists on New American Classics. Share plate including Duck Fat Fries and Beef Tartare, or be a little selfish and try the Ribeye "Tomahawk" all to yourself. 

   Satisfy every taste bud with our Las Vegas late night menu. The end of your night will taste a lot better with our classic Green Eggs + Ham dish. Stop by after your Vegas adventures and take a peek at our Las Vegas late night menu in our main dining room, as well as in the bar and lounge area. Tuesday & Thursdays - Sunday from 11pm to late. A perfect spot to grab a late night bite before hitting OMNIA.

This is a must if you are going to Vegas. The delivery was flawless both in the service and the food. We started with Beef Tartare & Sourdough, Hummus & Toasted Pita, Biscuits and Calamari Steak. For three that was a ton of food. The Tartare was a huge portion and wonderful taste, the Hummus was perhaps the least exciting offering but still good. The biscuits were to die for and you have to use the infused honey, you'll want a bowl! The calamari was served in steak finger fashion rather than old boring rings and again the sauce was excellent.
We then ordered a filet, short ribs and fish and chips. The fish and chips get served as part of an art deco arrangement of the whole real fish, very impressive. The short ribs were so soft you could have cut them with your napkin and the filet was cooked perfectly. I warn you every dish came out piping hot, get your drink ready.
You will have an unbelievable visit!

Had the pleasure of coming here one night after Seeing NERVO play at Omnia Nightclub. I didn't even know they had late night. One of the Cocktail server assistants told me about it while we were in Omnia. It had to have been around 3:30am or so. Pretty awesome how the place stays open late when the club is going on. We hurried up and ordered the chicken & waffles as we heard they were amazing! Service staff is on point! Our server Steve was highly knowledgeable about the food and also vouched for the said Chicken & waffles. They were indeed worthy of the hype surrounding them, haha! Food was brought out quick! Matt (food runner guy) asked if we needed anything and made sure we got al we needed to devour the luscious food (I said luscious). I would highly recommend coming here again and we probably will come by during normal dinner time as well. Food was awesome as well as the service. Now you guys know where to head after going to OMNIA!!! Ha! 

(Sorry no pics, I lost my phone before the night ended)

Sorry but, I will never eat there again! Not that the food was terrible, but just over priced. Service was lacking and the food was weak. Everything was spicy, which was ok for me but not my mother. She could not even get mustard for her 26$ hamburger, and there is something wrong with that.

Came here based on a mix of Yelp pictures and their menu offerings. Our Party of 9 had an 8pm reservation and was seated promptly. I was actually surprised the place was only half full and felt a little concerned I made a poor choice in restaurant especially since it was on the expensive side. However, it turned out I had nothing to worry about.  I split the Chicken Cobb salad and Mac n Cheese with a friend and both were super delicious. Especially the Mac n Cheese. And the portions were surprisingly large we couldn't finish either. Also tried their Habanero & coriander pickles which were free with Yelp check in and as strange as they sounds they were actually really good. 

it wasn't happy hour but they had 2 drink specials going for the night. A cosmo and a "bay breeze" which was basically vodka and tropical juices. It was tasty and on the strong side for only $8/ I came in expecting to spend over $100 but between the drink specials and portions large enough to split I managed to come in under $60, so just know this place doesn't HAVE to break your wallet. It's also right next to Omnia so well placed for pre-turnup meal and drinks. I will definitely be returning in the future.

So, funny thing....I have recommended Searsucker San Diego to many friends, who have loved it. But I have yet to go myself! So, when a location opened in Vegas, I knew I had to check it out.

First things first - park in the Forum shops valet or self parking, both are convenient to the restaurant. 

The restaurant was easy to find. If you continue past the sports book and poker room, you'll see Omnia and Searsucker is just next door to that. 

Note that they are only open for dinner (currently - not sure if that will change). They do offer a decent happy hour menu Monday - Friday.

The décor is very rustic and warm. When you enter, there is a large bar area with booths and seating. I was surprised at the size of the restaurant. While not small, it was smaller than I expected (in a good way). I love the open kitchen concept and that there is actually seating at the counter.

Here's what we had for food:

Duck fat fries with chipotle ketchup ($10) - REALLY good. Do yourself a favor and order these.

Shisito + ponzu ($7) - They say about 1 in every 10 is really hot, so be careful! I got a hot one and survived, but I love spicy stuff. There was tremendous flavor on the peppers and I'm glad I tried them.

Egg + Bacon "pork belly" ($19) - This was tasty as well, although the bacon was a bit too thick cut (IMO).

Cowboy Caviar ($11) - I've had Rocky Mountain Oysters before (at Coors Field) and swore to never try them again. Although, they were not properly prepared there and these were PHENOMENAL! Really, really good. You would have a hard time believing that this wasn't a fancy chicken nugget.

Shrimp "spicy" + Bacon grits ($17) - Delicious! I am not a huge fan of grits, but these were well made. The spicy shrimp was really delicious and basically the star of the dish though.

Beet salad ($16) - I've had an obsession with beets lately. This was really good and I especially enjoyed the fried goat cheese.

I would say that it's best to get a bunch of plates and share. The main entrees are on the high end, pricing wise. We were all happy with the smaller plates.

We also had a couple of signature cocktails, which were good. The beer list was decent, but nothing spectacular, which is a bit disappointing for a restaurant based in San Diego.

They will be offering a late night menu, on the nights that Omnia is open. I would expect this place to be a total shit show on those nights! The staff were all super friendly and knowledgeable, and Chef Malarkey was quite nice as well. I look forward to going back soon for a visit and trying some of the things we didn't get to try this time!

One of the best meals I have had in Las Vegas.  Specialty drinks were tasty and not bad price for the Strip.  Crab Cakes are the absolute best I have ever had and a must try!   We also had the steak tartare & pork butt both very good. The Chefs use of sauces and flavor combinations are wonderful!  Our waiter Chris was great as well as the rest of the wait staff that assisted. a very nice atmosphere.

Fabulous!  I recommend ordering tapas style to try many dishes.  We all got to try so much more this way. Loved the braised short rib, ceviche, mac n cheese. All incredible.  Didn't save room for hot chocolate chip cookies and milk, but ordered them anyway. No regrets!
Service was excellent, but rarely saw anyone smile. That was the only thing missing. 
I highly recommend this restaurant and can't wait to go back again.

I was excited to try one of the newest restaurants in Las Vegas and it did not disappoint! Great atmosphere, amazing menu selection, spectacular food! This restaurant is a MUST TRY! And request Lindsey...she, by far, was the best server I've ever had...very knowledgeable about the menu, attentive to our needs, and pushed this great dining experience over the top!!!

Seersucker is a great place to find an interesting and yet accessible meal on the strip and in Caesars palace. This place has some awesome staff and a great bar team that takes care of the patrons across the restaurant. They have some cool and tasty signature and craft cocktails that are certainly worth a try (or two, or three!) The food is well prepared and very well presented - they put their time into the dishes and make sure that it's done to your liking. The pricing is a bit high, but for an on-the-strip option is a great choice and well worth return visits. Happy hour is great and you can get some nice deals too - so keep an eye out! All in all this is a win win for me!
I love the ambiance and the cocktails. Chef Malarkey & Hakkasan Group have really done a great job  taking a see and be seen San Diego "locals restaurant" and turning it into a viable global brand.

We were sat promptly and the hostess was very nice.  Then we waited and waited.  Finally a server showed up.  He was very nice.  We ordered drink and they were good.  We then ordered appetizers and they were expensive and TINY.  I know that appetizers can be small, but they were smaller than I have ever seen.  The server was not attentive, never checked in on us.  We constantly had to ask the bus boy to get him.  The sliders were 2 tiny burgers and were tasty,  the ahi tacos were the size of those deep friend mini tacos from the frozen section at the store.  They were just ok.  The Ceviche was good also.  The guy who filled the water glasses was fantastic.  We drank a lot of water since we had to wait so long for drinks.

Top notch food 
Relaxed but upscale atmosphere
Friendly, knowledgeable waitstaff

Jenn took me to Searsucker for my most recent Birthday dinner.
We enjoyed sharing several offerings starting with the Blackened Ahi Tacos- small but packed with flavor.
Next was the Calamari Steak with Chili Honey Glaze and Apples- strongly recommended by our server-- thank goodness. This is NOT typical fried Calamari O's you could get at any ordinary chain place. No no no!! Think more of the difference in canned tuna and real fresh Ahi= yes now you get it! The Calamari Steak will change your life-- or at least your expectations of seafood for bit.
Lastly we shared The Braised Pork Butt Entree- a tower of flavor power! So melt in your mouth type tender. Whiskey Apples, Brussels Sprouts and Prosciutto round out the experience.

Also worth mention is the wide variety of hand crafted cocktails- especially the Jaleberry Strawpeno-- tequila with fruit and heat.

Ok, here is my update for a recent visit. They have changed chefs from our Meet up, and have also adjusted the menu, taking away my favorite Pork Belly Benedict which I send people here to try. Also gone, my Ballerina and the Czar cocktail. This makes me sad. :(

I had the eggs and bacon, and also the grilled cheese and tomato basil soup. The eggs and bacon was disappointing, the pork belly here was so dry and crunchy that it was almost inedible. The grilled cheese and tomato basil was pretty good. 

This is one of my pet peeves with restaurants, and that's taking good items off the menu. I'm sure there are numbers that say this wasn't selling or whatever. Looking over this menu, I really didn't see much that I enjoyed from our Yelp event left. I was definitely disappointed with the selections. 

Alas, I won't be back nor recommending it again. I'm sure people will still enjoy what they have to offer, and they have a great location. Time to find a new Strip restaurant to enjoy and take guests from out of town to.

I was invited by Brain Malarkey for his hospitality event, I had such a great time! The food the drinks the atmosphere was just great, he was very involved and answered all our questions, I had a little sample of the small eats such as duck fat fries and chipotle ketchup , shishito peppers, cheese and meats, eggs and pork belly and shrimp and grits... All was very flavorful and my favorite was the cowboy caviar!!! Aka BULLS BALLS lol... Best tasting balls ever! Also I had the Chardonnay it was very smooth... I had the Peter rabbit and jalaberry strawpeno!!!! I'm definitely going back for my 1 year wedding anniversary and my 30th birthday!!!
Very nice restaurant and great decor inside. Hanger steak was awesome and the whipped potatoes were delicious. Biscuits I could take a whole batch home if you like sweet honey biscuits.

You need to try this place and if you have go back!!  The staff was great. Eric was our waiter and was spot on. Had the opportunity to meet nick, asst GM, was a pleasure. Really s class operation. The food was great. Crab cake is straight crab meat.  The calamari steak with apple I wanted all to myself. We had other dishes and I enjoyed a Peter rabbit drink.  Best part of the night, milk and cookies. Can't wait to bring more clients and friends back. My go to for Caesars!!

We selected this restaurant for our party of 6 based on the reviews and food selection. We wanted something a little different, and the selections and review pictures looked quite interesting. It was an early dinner by Vegas standard, around 7pm. Hostess was wonderfully friendly and promptly seated us. 

The dinner started with an introduction from our server, Cesar.  He was really great from beginning to end.  We really enjoyed his friendliness and appreciated his attentive service. We wanted to have some fun during dinner, and Cesar played right along!  The entire service was great, perfectly timed and we were well attended the entire time. 

We chose a few share plates; Tomato and Burata (super delish), short ribs (succulent and tasty), and the duck fat fries (nicely seasoned and presented).  For our main courses most had the hanger steak.  It was perfectly cooked and tasted great. One word of caution: You better love garlic, like I do!  One person in our party had the burger, which she said was "amazing", and another had the Salmon (perfectly cooked).  As if that wasn't enough, we finished off with the awesomely decadent ice cream sandwich. Man, the flavors there were unbelievable. 

All in all, we each enjoyed the food and Cesar's excellent service.  We'd all recommend the place for a slightly different take on American classics.

This was our second visit to Searsuckers and each time the good was excellent. 

The fish and chips are some of the best we've ever had. The mac and cheese is superbly made and the lollipop buffalo chicken wings are finger licking good. We ordered multiple items, all were very good. 

Dessert is great too, we ordered the rocky road bread pudding and the chocolate chip cookies.

The appetizers were delicious. I had the buffalo wings and calamari, not disappointed. My meal was the skirt steak. It was a little salty, but the chimichurri was good. I would definitely recommend this place for its bar environment. It was a very social scene and the people were friendly.

I tried Searsucker with a group for a friend's birthday.... This was a great experience cause we got to try a variety of items! For my cocktail I chose the Jalaberry Strawpeno - which is a strawberry jalapeno tequila + lime + agave. This was a great mix of spicy and sweet! For appetizers we shared the cheddar puffers, mussels + chorizo + beer, brie "triple" + cranberry jam, "cowboy caviar" and the shrimp "spicy" + bacon grits.  I have to say that my favorites were the mussels and the shrimp with the grits! YUMM! For my entrée I chose the scallops "east coast" israeli couscous + almonds + citrus vinaigrette- this was fabulous! We then shared a variety of desserts- I have to say my favorite was the warm cookies with milk.

I absolutely enjoyed the entire experience at Searsucker! Will definitely be back!

I've been putting off writing this review since I was such a big fan of the restaurant in Scottsdale (which is now closed) but unfortunately my experience at the Vegas location was not a good one. A big issue was the staff; everyone from the hostess to the bussers seemed to not want to be there. Our server was very short with us while ordering and never really came back after that. Another dude brought us our food and he wasn't very friendly either. I burnt my hand pretty badly (it bubbled into a blister the next day) on one of the metal dishes they serve the food (straight from the oven?!?!) in and it took us forever to find someone to give us some ice since our water glasses were never even refilled.

The food was a disappointment as well. The menu was probably half the size of the AZ location so there wasn't much variety. Since it was late we decided on a few small plates to share. We got the corn (cooked well but very bland), the Mac and Cheese (really awful... the sauce was white and curdled) and also the small fried blobs they tried to pass off as tacos.

The decor in the place was nice but it was loud since it is open to the casino and also very dark for some unknown reason. Just not a pleasant experience. There are other better and cheaper places to go in Caesars so I will not be back.

Review is for happy hour at the bar.

I can't believe this is my first time back here since the YEE two years ago! We were seeing a show at the Colosseum and came a little early for some appetizers and drinks. It was surprisingly not busy for a Sunday night so we grabbed a seat at one of the hightops in the bar area. Our server Emily was right over to go over the HH menu and take our drink order. 

HH at Searsucker has some great deals. All food is $9 and drinks are $4-8 depending on if you order beer, wine or cocktails. I had the house chardonnay for $6 and it wasn't bad. We ordered the duck fat fries, lollipop wings, sliders and ahi tacos. 

The food starting arriving very quickly. The ahi tacos (3) came out first and they were fantastic. The ahi was super fresh and served in a wonton shell with limes and guac on the side. Next out was the lollipop wings. 9 wings covered in buffalo sauce served with blue cheese, carrots and celery. Another excellent dish. The fries and sliders arrived last. The fries were hot, fresh and crispy. Dusted with prosciutto and parmesan they were a perfect match for the sliders. 

Although the sliders were our least favorite of the four apps, they were still good. Slightly over cooked and quite small but the flavors were good. Debating on getting another order of the ahi tacos the dessert menu was brought out. As soon as I saw the rocky road bread pudding I knew I couldn't pass it up! 

The bread pudding was delivered with the marshmallows still on fire, melting on top of the chocolate bread pudding. With a side of fresh whipped cream and chocolate gelato this was an outstanding dessert that we quickly polished off. The food and service here is as good as when it opened two years ago and Im glad we came back.

Wanted a small bite so split the lollipop wings and tomato soup with grilled cheese. The wings were okay but the tomato soup was stellar, lots of flavor and that grilled cheese was the best I have EVER had. Service was great and food came out fast. I love the interior decor and all the different light fixtures especially the chandelier in the black cage. Really cool place! You won't be disappointed.

Lots of good small plates here - the goat cheese toast and calamari were great.  Wait staff was helpful and allowed us to order bit by bit so we could try several things without over ordering as small plates can sometimes be tough to judge. Tried the p, b & j old fashion, pretty good!  Mule was the hit drink of the night.  We will be back!

Nice stop for a pre-show bite! I thought it was located in the forum shops but it's in the casino. Service was friendly though a little slow - but it was pretty packed, probably due to the concert. They have a great happy hour - my husband got dogfish head on tap and I ordered the blueberry smash cocktail. We were running low on time so we ordered the lollipop chicken wings and tomatoe burrata. Both were tasty and a deal for the price! Next time we're gonna try the fries - we would definitely return to try their full menu.

Dinner on a Friday evening just a few days after they opened and Searsucker already had a decent amount of people seated, enjoying their food.

We were seated in an awkward table in a walkway on the way to the restroom so my chair got kicked and bumped on a number of occasions. If I were to return I would ask for a more secluded table.

I had the pleasure of enjoying a meal with several dining companions which gave us a chance to order and sample a number of items from the menu.

For a new restaurant service already seemed on point, but that may just have been our good fortune to get the only server in the restaurant that came over from the Searsucker location in San Diego. He was knowledgable, friendly and very attentive. 

Our plates came out in a well-balanced manner. Never inundating us with too much food so we were able to sample at a leisurely pace.

My favorites from the evening were the mahi, pork butt, egg and pork belly and surprisingly the strawberry salad. Each of these dishes were well-cooked and the flavors were on point. 

The rest of the food was good, but didn't leave a lasting impression with me. I love brussel sprouts but these weren't as crispy as I like and seemed drowned in garlic, not really allowing me to enjoy the flavor of the vegetable. I was in the minority in my opinion of this dish, so it might just be a personal preference. 

Of the desserts we sampled, the smores dish came out as a table favorite. Even I, who am neither a huge fan of chocolate or smores, enjoyed it, though I couldn't take more than a bite since it was rich. This dish is best shared. The rest of the desserts didn't really do as much for me, but they were decent. Again, I was in the minority on this opinion, so it may be due to my lack of sweet tooth. 

Searsucker is already ahead of the game after opening so recently. Good service, excellent location and decent food to boot. With their eclectic menu and late night availability I see them being successful in catering to the pre-show and after clubbing crowd quite well.

Probably my 10th time eating dining here......Service can be on the slower side, but the food is always consistent. 
The tomato soup and grilled cheese is my absolute favorite and now they are doing it table side. It's a big enough meal to not need anything else!!
Tonight we tried their newest "melon tomato shrimp" salad. Amazing! Yellow watermelon, yellow and red heirloom tomatoes (a little skimpy on the shrimp-only 3 and for 24$), but a total must try! 
They also offer an expedited Omnia nightclub entry when you spend 50$ on dinner which is pretty enticing if your looking to head there.
